content:
Is aesop a reasonable "drop-in" replacement for obviously? @Jannis Limperg

Sorry if this has been asked and answered elsewhere, but I couldn't find it.
They are definitely very different, but have a large overlap in what they can cope with.
There is aesop_cat which has some additional rules adapted for the category theory library.
and which can be used as a model for "subject specific" additions to the default rule set for aesop.

What Scott said. Looking at the default list of tactics that tidy (for which obviously is a synonym) calls, Aesop doesn't currently have an equivalent of ext, norm_cast, unfold_coes, unfold_aux and fsplit in the default rule set. But these can be added of course. (And probably for some of them it would make sense to add them to the builtin rules.)
Okay, thanks for those details. In Analysis.Normed.Group.Basic I just used aesop as the auto tactic for proving dist_eq. I think this should be reasonable, but we'll see if it causes issues.
I've been more recklessly doing this in category theory and haven't been bit (namely obviously -> aesop no cat)
